answers.author: Robert Carty
answers.text:
One thing I’d suggest is to look for the LGMF roster online and contact any current or former Fellows for their thoughts. In general, I think the personal statement should focus less on “I did this and that, therefore I think I would be good in local government” and more about how some personal event or experience has called you to public service/local government. Another angle could be how you think the efforts you put into a Fellowship will prepare you for the workplace after the Fellowship. The personal statement and case study both make up about 70% of the total score (see the FAQ at icma.org/lgmf for more details).
Just my thoughts – I’m not a reviewer, and of the twelve reviewers on the Advisory Board each has a different viewpoint so I can’t say there’s a silver bullet or “one way” to write an essay. Applicants are scored by three board members: an academic/former manager, a current manager, and a former Fellow. Scores are then blended/averaged.  All that said, one of the key requirements of being an effective manager is to communicate, convince, and inspire. If your essay can do that I think you should score fairly high.

author: Seth Eckard
text:
I'm looking for any advice one might have with regards to the ICMA LGMF application process.  For instance, how did you go about crafting your personal statement?  What did you decide to focus on in your responses?  Also, what do you think separated you from equally qualified candidates?  I really appreciate any guidance you can give me.  Thank you in advance for your time and consideration. 
Regards,
Seth
